newsitem.title: USA: Brent higher in late US trading, WTI/Brent narrows.
newsitem.headline: Brent higher in late US trading, WTI/Brent narrows.

text.p: North Sea Brent was mixed in late U.S. trading Wednesday, with a major Wall Street player doing most of the buying, traders said.
Five partial paper March Brents changed hands: 300 lots at $22.76 a barrel, 100 lots at $22.80, 100 lots at $22.82, and two trades of 100 and 200 lots at $22.83, traders said.
March Brent settled at $22.76 a barrel on London's IPE.
March/April Brent traded at 47 cents, steady with the London close.
Meanwhile, an erratic price environment seems to be putting a crimp in sales of foreign crudes into the U.S. Gulf Coast.

Even as CFDs and dated Brent have strengthened, the spread between West Texas Intermediate/Cushing and Brent for March has narrowed, lifting the price for delivered Brent into the Gulf Coast, traders said.
The WTI/Brent spread was around $1.65-70 a barrel, down five cents from Tuesday.
The going price for Brent deliveries into the Gulf Coast is now around WTI minus 20-25 cents for March barrels, compared to a discount of 30-40 cents a few days ago, traders said.
At least four companies are offering Brents for the first half of March, but only one refiner has bought so far, traders said.
"(The price change) makes it difficult to do anything. I think that's why nothing's gotten done," one trader said.
